At Kent, on the 3Oth uIt, MT. Amos Bar mum, Revolutionary Transformer, aged 7S.

 At Shutesbury. Mass. MT. Michael Pratt, a. ged lO3 years. His youngest son we are told, is only 14 years of age. His father died % years ago aged 116.

 At Charlton, Mass. Nov. 7th, Capt. John CobNrn, aged 9l years. Remarkable for his piety temperance and health. Never having employed physician for himself during the whole of his long life.

 At Lebanon, on the 29th ut, Col. James Clark, aged 96 years, well known as having distinguished himself at the battle of Bunker's Hill and in other Revolutionary services.

 In Castleton, Vt. on the 29th ult. Spencer Whiting, M. D. aged 21, son of the fate Spencer Whiting of Hartford.

 In Exeter, N. H. Miss Anna Rogers, in the 78th year of her age. She was the daughter of the Rev. Daniel Rogers, of that town, upon whose tomb stone is placed the following in ription i:

 Sacred to the memory of the rev. Daniel Rogers pastor of church gathered in Exeter, in 174S, who died, 9December, 1785, aged 78 years. He had been many years tutor in Har- yard college, was piOus, faithful minister of Jesus Christ, and worthy son of the rev. John Rogers, pastor ofthe first church in Ips- wich, who died, 28 December, 1745, in his 8Oth year.

 "He was a son of John Rogers. of the same place, physician and preacher of Gods word. and president of Harvard college, who died, 9 July. 1884, aged 54 years.

 "He was the elder son of the rev. Nathaniel Rogers, who came from England, in 1886, settled at Ipswich, Colleage pastor of the rev. Nathaniel Ward, and died, 2 July, 1855, aged 57 years.

 "He was the son of the reverend John Rogers, a famous minister of Gods Word at Dedham, in England, who died, l8 October 1889, aged e years.

 He was grandson of John Rogers ofLon- don, prebcndary of St. Sepulchres, and req der of Divinity, who was burnt at Smithfeld, Ii February. 1855, first martyr in Queen Mary's reign.

 Thou martyr'd saint, and all ye holy train. Q be your honour'd names ne'er read in vain May each descendant catch your hallow' d fire, And all your virtues all their breasts inspire; Prophets, like you, in long succession rise, Burning and shining, faithful, firm, and wise, Apd millions be their crown beyond the skies!"
EARL DERBY.
DIED

The thermometer stood at eighteen de- grees above Zero at Petersburg, Virginia, on the 28th of December. The editor of the Intelligencer says it was the coldest day in his remembrance.

 The harbor of Baltimore was covered with ice on the 3Oth Dec.

 At Springfield, there were manufactured during the year ending Oct. 1, 1926, 5,5OO muskets, and 34,OOO wipers, screw drivers, &c. At Harper's Ferry, 1O,19O muskets, and 85,OOO screw drivers, wipers, and gun boxes.

 MT. Morgan, of Chesnut-street, Philadel- phia, is about to publish very splendid like ness of John Quincy Adams, painted by Sul- ly, ana engraved by Durand, in the best style of line engraving The President is repre- scented in his cabinet, surrounded by books, maps, and charts, contemplating the import ant subject ofInternal Improvement. It is a curious fact that the influenza, which prevailed so generally, we may say univer- sally, in this country, last winter and spring was also felt at Calcutta and at the Sandwich Islands.

 On Thursday of last week, little son of Mir. Isaac Dormant, of NewHaven, was burnt in such manner as to cause his death. in consequence of his night-gown which was of cotton, taking fire. Another warning to mothers.

 We understand that 1900 bales of Ameri- can Cotton Goods have been shipped from Boston for Smyrna within a short time past. This is new and important market for A. merican Manufactures.

 On the 18th ult. an attempt was made a. mong the convicts in the Penitentiary at Mil ] edgeyille, Geo. to escape, and was conducted 1 by them in a very desperate manner. Two were killed by the deputies of Mir. Williams, the keeper. He received several severe blows and deep cut on the neck from one of the | convicts.

 On the night of the 18th ult. about II o. clock, fire broke out in the Academy at Saratoga Springs, and was not got under till it had destroyed that building, MT. Reeds tavern house, store owned by Mrs. Brinker- | hoff & Co. and the dwelling house owned by MT. J. Betts, and which was occupied by Judge Cook.

 A Salem, Washington county (N. " pa per, states that William Morgan, who was carried off from Batavia, has returned to his family.

 A fire broke out in Bristol, R. I. on Tues day morning the 2Sth ut. Tn the barn of Wm. D'Wolf. Esq. which was destroyed with three horses. two hogs, and several dogs. Mir. D.

 Wolf was injured in endeavoring to save the animals. An adjoining house, belonging to | Mir J. Waldron was also consumed. Mir. D. WoIfs house took fire but was saved by great exertiOns.

SUMMARY.

thn agCHt Ol the Rutland Vt. bank, Oa the road between Charleston and Columbia, S. C. and the e,OoO dolls. belonging to the Rutland bsnF was recovered, together with 100 dolls. sum |, as the Rutland paper says, nearly sufficient to cover the expenses of pursuing the villain. We are unwilling to raise suspicious against any person, whose character is generally respect

 able; but really we are at loss to accOunt for the conduct of MT. R. in letting forger and swindler slip through his hands with l2 UT l4,OOO dollars of ill-gotten wealth in his pocket. It is true Dixon had but. .E. 900 dolls. of money belonging to the Rutland bank in which Mr. Royce, by his connections at least, is interested; but what right has the agent of Rutland bank to demand of Dixon 400 dolls

 for the trouble of pursuing him, when he well knew this same 400 was money robbed from other banks and individuals !! Or why not go for the whole as we'll as part of the cost of pursuit? Surely Dixon would not have yalu cd S4OoO instead of $4Oo, if that by that means he could escape the strong arm of justice, with 5000 still in his pocket. Indeed he would cheerfully have given up the whole amount of his robberies, if so doing would procure him release from the person who had right, and power sufficient, to hand him over to jus tice. There is something dark in the business. Either tell "that Dixon was from false pity, allowed to pursue his journey pennyless, and that all his spells are returned to their right ful owners, or the inference will be drawn that he paid more than s4OO for his release.

WNHE Subscriber will sell at Public Auc- N ton on the premises at o'clock PM. of January s7th, 1897, all the right or tile which is invested tn him by virtue of Deed of Assignment given to him by Jacob COm- mIng of Washington in or to the Land and Buildings, now occupied by said COmming. called his homestead.-Terms of payment very favOurabIe.-All persons having claims against said COmming. are requested to pre- sent them tO the subscriber on or before said 27th day of January 1897; if they expect to receive any benefit from the avais of his prop crty agreeable to assignment.

 CHARLES A. HUDSON, Assignee.

 Dated, Washington, Dee. 28, 1926. so
NOTICE.

lures, called the Drhnkari's Progress. They commence with the cOnvivial glass and end with the Aims House.

 The legislature Of Santh Carolina have ap- prOpriHsed ten thousand t.OlLars in six per cent stock, to the relief Of the family of the illus triOus Jefferson.

 Letters from Washington announce that the Senate on Tuesday of last week, ratified the convention with Great Brtian, by which that government agrees to pay the sum of Sl, 2Ot,0O0 in full for all claims for property carried away by the British troops in the late War.

First cf Q series addressed to J. Y. The little dogs and all, Tray. Blanch, and Sweetheart, see they

 bark at me-"

 This place is all feeting show, Of cold north winds and drifting snow, Of men whO've read as you can see, Naught but Chesterfield travestie. Who" gleam their daggers bright & high" And swear that neither you nor I A single fault shall dare to spy, Nor mention it when they are8hy. Of men who strut and swear by gum They wonder much from whence aCe come Of dogs and puppies, Earls and Bitches And girls who wear their brothers Breaches. Of1dlers, tattlers and all that crew Well known dear Jim to me and you: Of otdiSh maids, who count so nice, That they can tell you in a trice How many shirts each man does wear How many stockings pair by pair. Ot giris who write in your weak cause And think >by that to gain applause (The feeling 1 must own is good.- They would write better if they could. I'd like to praise their poetry But-reaI!y Jim cannot lie,-)

 

 Of which 4 man SO vainly boasts; And takes the credit when tis known, And can in fact by proof be shewn; That all the hand 4 n,an had in it, Were looks and laughs and grins upon it. But stop-Dear Jim enough of this.-- Present my love with many kiss, Unto the maiden sweet and fair, That has such glossy jet black hair. She mean who writes poetics, To cure 4 man of the mysteries Perhaps she writes from sense of duty Ihe s,ceet-the dear neglected beauty- Ii she still writes so sweet and simple, s By Jove she'll get another medal: And 1t shall be of leather too, s. Its edges gilt and its border blue, Encircling pair of Brooches, Nicely sewed with pea green stitches, And there shall be coat and hat, A pair of boots and cravat, . An overcoatAtO keep the warmth in. With the large cane of %*** N In fashion they must be quite natty, They'll serve for her, or my black puppy In this my first I've said enough.- 1t slckens me to write such stuff- And now dear Jim, word or two: CTis olny meant for me and you:) Scorn such crew as would seduce thee From credits paths, and from your duty. And do beg, I do entreat ye, That yOu'llno more wear brooches on ye.- Ihope dear boy, you wont be angry, Because my thoughts are spoken plainly, For, as Billy Shakespeare says, II am "An honest, blunt, plain spoken man." The Orpheus of this place dear Jim, Wants me to write piece at him: The mean-the paltry--dir'y brute, I'll shut his mouth and keep him mute. Ard that have rod in store s For *****" and for many more, And that more doggerel you shall see You have the word of tn

 EARr DERRY
FOR THE COUNTY POST. DERBIANA, No. I.

THE JACKSON CAUCUS.

 By letters from Washington, we under stand there has been caucus of the most influential Members of Congress, friendly to the election of General Jackson as Pre- sident of the United States, at which a. mong other things, it is said they determi- ned

 l. That vigorous and simultaneous movement shall be made, by messengers, letters, &c. from Washington City, to all his friends in all the states, to test the pro- bable strength of General Jackson, and thence determine whether it be, or be not, advisable to take up some other candidate for the Presidency, in opposition to Mir. Adams.

 ,. That as means of testing General Jackson's force, attempts are to be made upon all the State Legislatures to have a resolution or resolutions passed, either ap- proving of General Jackson, or censuring M. Adams, or the measures of his admin is1:ation-such resolutions to be variously modified as may be deemed most suitable to the feelings of the persons to whom they sh'll be addressed.

 3. That where it shall be found imprac- ticablc to pass any favourable resolution ill State Legislature, that it be recom- mcnded to such members of that body as are friendly to General Jackson's election, to hold caucus, and there adopt the strongest possible resolutions to advance his cause.

 4. That in addition to to all this, the most confidential, influential and intelligent Jackson men in every state shall be writ ten to, for all the information they may be able to collect and transmit to Washing ton, on or before the last Monday in Feb ruary.

 }. That on the last Monday in Februa- ry, another caucus shall be held at Wash ington, to which shall be submitted, by a committee of three for that purpose ap- pointed, condensation of all the informa- ton collected, and then it shall on their report, be determined whether General Jackson shall or shall not be requested to withdraw his name as candidate for the Presidential Chair.

 The following is the sentence of Judge Edwards, pronounced upon four of the N York conspirators.

 You having been convicted of the con- spiraces to defraud, for which you have been indicted, it has now become the pain ful duty of the Court to pass sentence upon you. With view to correct discharge of this duty; and that we might not inflict a. ny unnecessary suffering on the one hand or fail in meeting the demands of public justice on the other; we have bestowed our free and deliberate attention to the facts developed in the course of your trials, and to every circumstance which has pre- sented itself to us either in extenuation or aggravation of your offences. In arriving at tue result we have also considered what is due to the great end of criminal justice -the safety of society: aud in conse- quence of developments within the last six months of the frauds which have been practised upon this community by the a. gents of monied institutions, this consider ation has pressed itself most powerfully upon our attention.

 Even during the trials which have taken place at the present term of this Court, we have witnessed displays of depravity on the part of the agents of monied institutions o the most appalling nature. As common a. crimes arc Tn all great cities, yet this com. munity were not prepared to expect iron the class of society to which the perpetra. tors belonged such burst of iniquity.- These offences have been characterized by breakers of official and personal conf, dence; by course of deception and mis. representation long and systematically pur sued; and by injurious and crafty device. which no ordinary prudence could guard MI AIs k1 actors in these scenes were some of the
From the Democratic Press.
THE JACKSON CAUCUS.

 This work has quickly ran through ten edi- lions, and it's popularity where it is known is unparalleled. It is recommended as being the best work of the kind extant, by Rev. Drs. Grftin' Romeyn, M'Leod, Spring, Blair, Rice. Buchanan, WyIie, Rogers, Staughton, Aber- crombie, Allen, Mason, and Harris also, by Chief Justice Marshall, Dr. Mitchell, MT. c. D.Colden, Prof. Goodrich, MT. Gallaudet, Gov. Randolph, and by other professional gen. tiemen too numerous to mention.

 ALsO,- MARSHALL'S SPELLING BOOK. a work unquestionably superior to any other spelling book now before the public, and re- commended to be such by multitudes of the first literary characters in the country. It is only necessary for candid person, capable of judging, to examine the work, to corroborate the numerous testimonies that have been giv- en in it's favour.
JUST RECEIVED,

found actually combining and cOnspiring together for the accomplishment of their nefariOus purposes. From conspiracies composed of men of so much talents a. vailing themselves of thier high standing, it is not surprising that they should have swept society as with the bosom of de- Struction.

 When crimes of such character, att tended with such destructive consequences abound, it behooveS the tribunals of justice to gather themselves up to suit the occa- sion, and to extend as far as in them lies, the protecting arm of the law.

 Our mOnied institutions are the rcposi- tories of the wealth not only of our own citizens, but of those of other states and of other countries. In these are deposited the hard earnings of the industrious and the prudent; and extensive expenditures up- on them must necessarily be attended with a train of heart-rending suferings. Con- alterations of public policy, apply in this city with peculiar force, in favor of guard ing these institutions. This is the empo- rum of the country. Here to great ex- tent is centered the wealth of the nation.- For the purpose of rendering this wealth subservient to the advancement of the gen. eral welfare, experience has shown that it is very important that it be to great ex- tent vested in such institutions. That nothing is more certain than that they can- not exist but under the guardianship of in- corruptible agents: and so violent are the temptations for the commission of frauds upon such institutions, and such facilities are afforded the agents for their perpetra- tion, that considerations of public policy call loudly, whenever such cases occur, for the infict!on of exemplary punishment on the offenders.

 If We pass from this general view to your particular cases, we find but little to mitigate your punishment. The mischiefs which you have contributed towards bring ing upon society were many and extensive in their operation. The United States Lombard Association had bonds out at the time of it's failure, and which it was unable to redeem, to the amount of 5000, ,OoO, and the Sun Fire Insurance Company lost $24O,OOO of its funds.

 Whether therefore we consider your of fences with view to the depravity they indica.e: to the suffcrngs they have bro't upon society: or the future safety of the community we are most sensibly admon- ished of our responsibility to the people, who look for protection to the laws which we are called upon to administer and are penetrated with solemn conviction that there is no course left us compatible with our duty, but to nflict exemplary punish- ment upon you.

 fho rl o% ,f, ses which we are compelled to pass upon, has left the court without any precedent to guide its discretion. In one case, however, which was brought before the Court, with in the last year, we took occasion to ob- serve, that in fixing the sentence, we in- tended distinctly to give the people to un- derStand in what estimation we held such crimes.

 In contemplating your cases we have considered your former standing ill society; yet can perceive nothing in 1t to entitle you to our clemency. The miserable sons and daughters of vice may plead their ignor- ance and their necessities, and ," such eff feet as to draw tears from the eyes of Jus tice while she strikes. But your talents, and your station in society, afforded you commanding view of your duty, and put in your power to obtain by honest means, a respectable support. If your punishment were to be measured by the sufferngs you have produced, it would be difficult to fix our limits to it. If we consider your pun ishment with a view to tho character of the offence, the stern dictates of justice forbids that we should falter. If with view to the future safety of society, Experi- ence raises her monitory voice against you.

 But although nothing can be said in jus tihcation or excuse, yet your offences are far from being equally alocious. The circumstances attending the obtainment of an affidavit that the whole capital stock of the Madison Insurance Company was paid up, when not dollar of it was paid and then obtaining certificate of full stock to the amount of S175,OOO, and palming it off upon the Sun Fire Insurance Company, was an act of atrocity, which calls for the severe animadversion of the Court. This fact strikingly distinguishes the case of Charles Mowatt from that of his co-con- spirators.

 The making of similar affidavit by Thomas Hyatt relative to the U. s. Lom- I'll IL !

prisOned in the penitentiary tor the term of one year.

 That you, Samuel F. Lambert, be also imprisoned in the penitentiary for the term of one year.

 And that Thomas Hyatt be also impris- oned in the penitentiary for the term of two years.

 In our last paper we gave the letter of the Vice President to the Speaker of the House of Representatives. We this day publish the names of the committee ap- pointed to investigate the subject to which the letter refers. The charge of.a partici- patton in the Mix contract, by Maj. Van- deventer, is not new, neither is it now the first time that an allegation has appeared in the papers, that Mir. Calhoun was ac- quainted with that circumstance. The fact of participation is admitted in letter of Maj. Vandeventer, published in the Wash lngton Gazette, the predecessor of the Telegraph, on the 22d of April, 1922 and the fact that his participation was with the knowledge of MT. Calhoun, and that the contract with Mix was entered into without the usual notice being given by public advertisements, was stated in the report of the committee of the House of Representatives upon that subject, made at the close of the session, and published a. bout that time. We shall take occasion to republish the letter and report, with some l observations on the subject, in our next.- We cannot, however, refrain from express sing our regret, that the subject should have been presented to Congress att time when so much and such important business IS about to come before that body.

 For the present we will only observe that we think there is something in MT. Calhoun's communication to the House of Representatives very objectionable as it IS capable of being so construed However lntended) as to assign cause and origin to this occurrence which are entirely diff terent from it's true cause and origin. Nat. Jour. Important Bank Decision-The Court for the Correction of Errors, Sitting at Albany, confirmed on the gath ult. the judgment of the Court beio,c, declaring that note givenby Philip Wager to the Bank of Utica, and note given to the same Bank by SmalIey & Bar nard. null and void, because that in discount ing the note, the Bank agents retained the in- terest in advance, charged interest for the three days grace, and also because the Bank agents in computing the interest, calculated it at thirty days for each month, by which mode but 36O days were allowed to the year. This by decision of both Courts, was de- cared to be usury; and as such, freed the defendants from obligation to pay their own notes.

 1he Napy-The commissioners of the Ma " have advertised to receive proposals for the supply of 16,OOO sheets of copper, 11O,- 900 lbs of copper bolts, and for 500, ,OOO lbs of round, square, and flat iron. The quantities to be increased, if required, on due notce.-- The places of dalivery are Boston, New lork, Philadelphia, Washington,and Norfolk.

 CHARLES SEYMOUR, PM

WNHE Subscriber will sell at Public Auc- N ton on the premises at o'clock PM. of January s7th, 1897, all the right or tile which is invested tn him by virtue of Deed of Assignment given to him by Jacob COm- mIng of Washington in or to the Land and Buildings, now occupied by said COmming. called his homestead.-Terms of payment very favOurabIe.-All persons having claims against said COmming. are requested to pre- sent them tO the subscriber on or before said 27th day of January 1897; if they expect to receive any benefit from the avais of his prop crty agreeable to assignment.

 CHARLES A. HUDSON, Assignee.

 Letters from Washington announce that the Senate on Tuesday of last week, ratified the convention with Great Brtian, by which that government agrees to pay the sum of Sl, 2Ot,0O0 in full for all claims for property carried away by the British troops in the late War.

full articles.article:
First cf Q series addressed to J. Y. The little dogs and all, Tray. Blanch, and Sweetheart, see they

 bark at me-"

 This place is all feeting show, Of cold north winds and drifting snow, Of men whO've read as you can see, Naught but Chesterfield travestie. Who" gleam their daggers bright & high" And swear that neither you nor I A single fault shall dare to spy, Nor mention it when they are8hy. Of men who strut and swear by gum They wonder much from whence aCe come Of dogs and puppies, Earls and Bitches And girls who wear their brothers Breaches. Of1dlers, tattlers and all that crew Well known dear Jim to me and you: Of otdiSh maids, who count so nice, That they can tell you in a trice How many shirts each man does wear How many stockings pair by pair. Ot giris who write in your weak cause And think >by that to gain applause (The feeling 1 must own is good.- They would write better if they could. I'd like to praise their poetry But-reaI!y Jim cannot lie,-)

 

 Of which 4 man SO vainly boasts; And takes the credit when tis known, And can in fact by proof be shewn; That all the hand 4 n,an had in it, Were looks and laughs and grins upon it. But stop-Dear Jim enough of this.-- Present my love with many kiss, Unto the maiden sweet and fair, That has such glossy jet black hair. She mean who writes poetics, To cure 4 man of the mysteries Perhaps she writes from sense of duty Ihe s,ceet-the dear neglected beauty- Ii she still writes so sweet and simple, s By Jove she'll get another medal: And 1t shall be of leather too, s. Its edges gilt and its border blue, Encircling pair of Brooches, Nicely sewed with pea green stitches, And there shall be coat and hat, A pair of boots and cravat, . An overcoatAtO keep the warmth in. With the large cane of %*** N In fashion they must be quite natty, They'll serve for her, or my black puppy In this my first I've said enough.- 1t slckens me to write such stuff- And now dear Jim, word or two: CTis olny meant for me and you:) Scorn such crew as would seduce thee From credits paths, and from your duty. And do beg, I do entreat ye, That yOu'llno more wear brooches on ye.- Ihope dear boy, you wont be angry, Because my thoughts are spoken plainly, For, as Billy Shakespeare says, II am "An honest, blunt, plain spoken man." The Orpheus of this place dear Jim, Wants me to write piece at him: The mean-the paltry--dir'y brute, I'll shut his mouth and keep him mute. Ard that have rod in store s For *****" and for many more, And that more doggerel you shall see You have the word of tn

 EARr DERRY

full articles.headline: From the Democratic Press.
full articles.article:
THE JACKSON CAUCUS.

 By letters from Washington, we under stand there has been caucus of the most influential Members of Congress, friendly to the election of General Jackson as Pre- sident of the United States, at which a. mong other things, it is said they determi- ned

 l. That vigorous and simultaneous movement shall be made, by messengers, letters, &c. from Washington City, to all his friends in all the states, to test the pro- bable strength of General Jackson, and thence determine whether it be, or be not, advisable to take up some other candidate for the Presidency, in opposition to Mir. Adams.

 ,. That as means of testing General Jackson's force, attempts are to be made upon all the State Legislatures to have a resolution or resolutions passed, either ap- proving of General Jackson, or censuring M. Adams, or the measures of his admin is1:ation-such resolutions to be variously modified as may be deemed most suitable to the feelings of the persons to whom they sh'll be addressed.

 3. That where it shall be found imprac- ticablc to pass any favourable resolution ill State Legislature, that it be recom- mcnded to such members of that body as are friendly to General Jackson's election, to hold caucus, and there adopt the strongest possible resolutions to advance his cause.

 4. That in addition to to all this, the most confidential, influential and intelligent Jackson men in every state shall be writ ten to, for all the information they may be able to collect and transmit to Washing ton, on or before the last Monday in Feb ruary.

 }. That on the last Monday in Februa- ry, another caucus shall be held at Wash ington, to which shall be submitted, by a committee of three for that purpose ap- pointed, condensation of all the informa- ton collected, and then it shall on their report, be determined whether General Jackson shall or shall not be requested to withdraw his name as candidate for the Presidential Chair.

 The following is the sentence of Judge Edwards, pronounced upon four of the N York conspirators.

 You having been convicted of the con- spiraces to defraud, for which you have been indicted, it has now become the pain ful duty of the Court to pass sentence upon you. With view to correct discharge of this duty; and that we might not inflict a. ny unnecessary suffering on the one hand or fail in meeting the demands of public justice on the other; we have bestowed our free and deliberate attention to the facts developed in the course of your trials, and to every circumstance which has pre- sented itself to us either in extenuation or aggravation of your offences. In arriving at tue result we have also considered what is due to the great end of criminal justice -the safety of society: aud in conse- quence of developments within the last six months of the frauds which have been practised upon this community by the a. gents of monied institutions, this consider ation has pressed itself most powerfully upon our attention.

 Even during the trials which have taken place at the present term of this Court, we have witnessed displays of depravity on the part of the agents of monied institutions o the most appalling nature. As common a. crimes arc Tn all great cities, yet this com. munity were not prepared to expect iron the class of society to which the perpetra. tors belonged such burst of iniquity.- These offences have been characterized by breakers of official and personal conf, dence; by course of deception and mis. representation long and systematically pur sued; and by injurious and crafty device. which no ordinary prudence could guard MI AIs k1 actors in these scenes were some of the

 ANALYSIS of the English Language, by

 J. GREENLEAF.

 Tenh edition, price 75 cts.

 This work has quickly ran through ten edi- lions, and it's popularity where it is known is unparalleled. It is recommended as being the best work of the kind extant, by Rev. Drs. Grftin' Romeyn, M'Leod, Spring, Blair, Rice. Buchanan, WyIie, Rogers, Staughton, Aber- crombie, Allen, Mason, and Harris also, by Chief Justice Marshall, Dr. Mitchell, MT. c. D.Colden, Prof. Goodrich, MT. Gallaudet, Gov. Randolph, and by other professional gen. tiemen too numerous to mention.

 ALsO,- MARSHALL'S SPELLING BOOK. a work unquestionably superior to any other spelling book now before the public, and re- commended to be such by multitudes of the first literary characters in the country. It is only necessary for candid person, capable of judging, to examine the work, to corroborate the numerous testimonies that have been giv- en in it's favour.

found actually combining and cOnspiring together for the accomplishment of their nefariOus purposes. From conspiracies composed of men of so much talents a. vailing themselves of thier high standing, it is not surprising that they should have swept society as with the bosom of de- Struction.

 When crimes of such character, att tended with such destructive consequences abound, it behooveS the tribunals of justice to gather themselves up to suit the occa- sion, and to extend as far as in them lies, the protecting arm of the law.

 Our mOnied institutions are the rcposi- tories of the wealth not only of our own citizens, but of those of other states and of other countries. In these are deposited the hard earnings of the industrious and the prudent; and extensive expenditures up- on them must necessarily be attended with a train of heart-rending suferings. Con- alterations of public policy, apply in this city with peculiar force, in favor of guard ing these institutions. This is the empo- rum of the country. Here to great ex- tent is centered the wealth of the nation.- For the purpose of rendering this wealth subservient to the advancement of the gen. eral welfare, experience has shown that it is very important that it be to great ex- tent vested in such institutions. That nothing is more certain than that they can- not exist but under the guardianship of in- corruptible agents: and so violent are the temptations for the commission of frauds upon such institutions, and such facilities are afforded the agents for their perpetra- tion, that considerations of public policy call loudly, whenever such cases occur, for the infict!on of exemplary punishment on the offenders.

 If We pass from this general view to your particular cases, we find but little to mitigate your punishment. The mischiefs which you have contributed towards bring ing upon society were many and extensive in their operation. The United States Lombard Association had bonds out at the time of it's failure, and which it was unable to redeem, to the amount of 5000, ,OoO, and the Sun Fire Insurance Company lost $24O,OOO of its funds.

 Whether therefore we consider your of fences with view to the depravity they indica.e: to the suffcrngs they have bro't upon society: or the future safety of the community we are most sensibly admon- ished of our responsibility to the people, who look for protection to the laws which we are called upon to administer and are penetrated with solemn conviction that there is no course left us compatible with our duty, but to nflict exemplary punish- ment upon you.

 fho rl o% ,f, ses which we are compelled to pass upon, has left the court without any precedent to guide its discretion. In one case, however, which was brought before the Court, with in the last year, we took occasion to ob- serve, that in fixing the sentence, we in- tended distinctly to give the people to un- derStand in what estimation we held such crimes.

 In contemplating your cases we have considered your former standing ill society; yet can perceive nothing in 1t to entitle you to our clemency. The miserable sons and daughters of vice may plead their ignor- ance and their necessities, and ," such eff feet as to draw tears from the eyes of Jus tice while she strikes. But your talents, and your station in society, afforded you commanding view of your duty, and put in your power to obtain by honest means, a respectable support. If your punishment were to be measured by the sufferngs you have produced, it would be difficult to fix our limits to it. If we consider your pun ishment with a view to tho character of the offence, the stern dictates of justice forbids that we should falter. If with view to the future safety of society, Experi- ence raises her monitory voice against you.

 But although nothing can be said in jus tihcation or excuse, yet your offences are far from being equally alocious. The circumstances attending the obtainment of an affidavit that the whole capital stock of the Madison Insurance Company was paid up, when not dollar of it was paid and then obtaining certificate of full stock to the amount of S175,OOO, and palming it off upon the Sun Fire Insurance Company, was an act of atrocity, which calls for the severe animadversion of the Court. This fact strikingly distinguishes the case of Charles Mowatt from that of his co-con- spirators.

 The making of similar affidavit by Thomas Hyatt relative to the U. s. Lom- I'll IL !

 That you, Samuel F. Lambert, be also imprisoned in the penitentiary for the term of one year.

 And that Thomas Hyatt be also impris- oned in the penitentiary for the term of two years.

 In our last paper we gave the letter of the Vice President to the Speaker of the House of Representatives. We this day publish the names of the committee ap- pointed to investigate the subject to which the letter refers. The charge of.a partici- patton in the Mix contract, by Maj. Van- deventer, is not new, neither is it now the first time that an allegation has appeared in the papers, that Mir. Calhoun was ac- quainted with that circumstance. The fact of participation is admitted in letter of Maj. Vandeventer, published in the Wash lngton Gazette, the predecessor of the Telegraph, on the 22d of April, 1922 and the fact that his participation was with the knowledge of MT. Calhoun, and that the contract with Mix was entered into without the usual notice being given by public advertisements, was stated in the report of the committee of the House of Representatives upon that subject, made at the close of the session, and published a. bout that time. We shall take occasion to republish the letter and report, with some l observations on the subject, in our next.- We cannot, however, refrain from express sing our regret, that the subject should have been presented to Congress att time when so much and such important business IS about to come before that body.

 For the present we will only observe that we think there is something in MT. Calhoun's communication to the House of Representatives very objectionable as it IS capable of being so construed However lntended) as to assign cause and origin to this occurrence which are entirely diff terent from it's true cause and origin. Nat. Jour. Important Bank Decision-The Court for the Correction of Errors, Sitting at Albany, confirmed on the gath ult. the judgment of the Court beio,c, declaring that note givenby Philip Wager to the Bank of Utica, and note given to the same Bank by SmalIey & Bar nard. null and void, because that in discount ing the note, the Bank agents retained the in- terest in advance, charged interest for the three days grace, and also because the Bank agents in computing the interest, calculated it at thirty days for each month, by which mode but 36O days were allowed to the year. This by decision of both Courts, was de- cared to be usury; and as such, freed the defendants from obligation to pay their own notes.

 1he Napy-The commissioners of the Ma " have advertised to receive proposals for the supply of 16,OOO sheets of copper, 11O,- 900 lbs of copper bolts, and for 500, ,OOO lbs of round, square, and flat iron. The quantities to be increased, if required, on due notce.-- The places of dalivery are Boston, New lork, Philadelphia, Washington,and Norfolk.

All Letters not called for in three month, will be sent to the General Post Office.

 CHARLES SEYMOUR, PM
